item.title: Immersion
item.description: A dynamic series of underwater portraits of Shakespeare actors using water's natural surface tension to create incredible textured backgrounds as they dive through the surface.

item.title: Epanding Spheres for Lincoln
item.description: Hobermans iconic expanding sphere has been paired with another American icon: Lincoln. Twin custom-designed spheres were prominently installed within the automotive brands display at the 2012 North American International Auto Show. To convey the Lincoln brands revitalization and emphasis on refined design, display designer Imagination commissioned Hobermans kinetic sculptures to contribute to the booths art-gallery ambiencefostering a connection between guests and the Lincoln brand.
item.content:encoded: Hobermans iconic expanding sphere has been paired with another American icon: Lincoln. Twin custom-designed spheres were prominently installed within the automotive brands display at the 2012 North American International Auto Show. To convey the Lincoln brands revitalization and emphasis on refined design, display designer Imagination commissioned Hobermans kinetic sculptures to contribute to the booths art-gallery ambiencefostering a connection between guests and the Lincoln brand.

item.title: Nestea - The Start of Something Different.
item.description: The Start Of Something Different campaign positions NESTEA as a catalyst for the start of new, unexpected and exciting possibilities. Across all media, NESTEA is celebrating people who are prepared to start new endeavours - including a Start-O-Matic Facebook application, which empowers consumers to embrace something new. Print and posters were created in collaboration with famed illustrators including Alex Trochut, Cody Hudson and Supermundane.
item.content:encoded: The Start Of Something Different campaign positions NESTEA as a catalyst for the start of new, unexpected and exciting possibilities. Across all media, NESTEA is celebrating people who are prepared to start new endeavours - including a Start-O-Matic Facebook application, which empowers consumers to embrace something new. Print and posters were created in collaboration with famed illustrators including Alex Trochut, Cody Hudson and Supermundane.

item.title: The Terminator (1984)
item.description: A cyborg is sent back in time by the sinister computer network Skynet to murder a woman who will one day give birth to the leader of the militia destined to end the coming robo-apocalypse.
item.content:encoded: A cyborg is sent back in time by the sinister computer network Skynet to murder a woman who will one day give birth to the leader of the militia destined to end the coming robo-apocalypse.

item.title: MUSEVI
item.description: A new elevated museum complete with an outdoor amphitheater at its base. MUSEVI is phase one of a three-phased Master Plan for Paseo Tabasco. By physically connecting two otherwise insulated lakes, Vaso Cencalli and Lagoon of Illusions, MUSEVI proposes a new form of exhibition and public space that encourages connectivity and social gathering. Likewise, the accompanying amphitheater has become a new focal point for Tomas Garrido Park. And with parts of the building protruding into and over the landscape, the museum, at the same time, encourages an intimate and reflective contemplation of the surrounding nature, if not acting as an unequivocal celebration thereof.
item.content:encoded: A new elevated museum complete with an outdoor amphitheater at its base. MUSEVI is phase one of a three-phased Master Plan for Paseo Tabasco. By physically connecting two otherwise insulated lakes, Vaso Cencalli and Lagoon of Illusions, MUSEVI proposes a new form of exhibition and public space that encourages connectivity and social gathering. Likewise, the accompanying amphitheater has become a new focal point for Tomas Garrido Park. And with parts of the building protruding into and over the landscape, the museum, at the same time, encourages an intimate and reflective contemplation of the surrounding nature, if not acting as an unequivocal celebration thereof.

item.title: Impressionist WP Theme
item.description: This WP theme was developed in March, 2012, but I only make it available now, as it is ready for sale. Impressionist WP was developed based on the Impressionist User Interface Pack, and both shows the possibilities of the UI Pack and acts as a separate WordPress theme. This WP theme has simultaneously 3 layouts you can use: Blog / Magazine Layout, Corporate Layout and Portfolio Layout.
item.content:encoded: This WP theme was developed in March, 2012, but I only make it available now, as it is ready for sale. Impressionist WP was developed based on the Impressionist User Interface Pack, and both shows the possibilities of the UI Pack and acts as a separate WordPress theme. This WP theme has simultaneously 3 layouts you can use: Blog / Magazine Layout, Corporate Layout and Portfolio Layout.

item.title: A box called Lowdi
item.description: He's small and easy-going - light-hearted but very social. He's good on the phone and is a massive music fan. He's a romantic. While he tends to be a little loud, he likes nothing more than to just blend into the background and help set the scene. He looks great in black and he's not attached... to anything.
item.content:encoded: He's small and easy-going - light-hearted but very social. He's good on the phone and is a massive music fan. He's a romantic. While he tends to be a little loud, he likes nothing more than to just blend into the background and help set the scene. He looks great in black and he's not attached... to anything.

item.title: Chicken Point Cabin
item.description: The idea for the Tom Kundig-designed cabin is that of a lakeside shelter in the woodsa little box with a big window that opens to the surrounding landscape. The cabins big window-wall (30 feet by 20 feet) opens the entire living space to the forest and lake. Materials are low maintenanceconcrete block, steel, concrete floors and plywoodin keeping with the notion of a cabin, and left unfinished to naturally age and acquire a patina that fits in with the natural setting. The cabin sleeps ten.
item.content:encoded: The idea for the Tom Kundig-designed cabin is that of a lakeside shelter in the woodsa little box with a big window that opens to the surrounding landscape. The cabins big window-wall (30 feet by 20 feet) opens the entire living space to the forest and lake. Materials are low maintenanceconcrete block, steel, concrete floors and plywoodin keeping with the notion of a cabin, and left unfinished to naturally age and acquire a patina that fits in with the natural setting. The cabin sleeps ten.

item.title: Fall 2012
item.description: Lela Rose Fall 2012 centers around the fusion of structure and movement as seen in the works of Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava. Calatravas focus on the poetics of motion combines romanticism with functionality as seen in linear labyrinth organza, hazed floral embroideries and carbonized silk. Both an architect and engineer, Calatravas signature bridges and railway stations set the backdrop for long, angular silhouettes. Floor length day time dresses in cable-stayed plaid and grid lace stove pipe sleeves effortlessly balance geometry with a natural fluidity. Brick fil coupe?, galvanized organza, and silk cloque? are highlighted in colors such as rust, sulfurous amber, dark bronze and white silver.
item.content:encoded: Lela Rose Fall 2012 centers around the fusion of structure and movement as seen in the works of Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava. Calatravas focus on the poetics of motion combines romanticism with functionality as seen in linear labyrinth organza, hazed floral embroideries and carbonized silk. Both an architect and engineer, Calatravas signature bridges and railway stations set the backdrop for long, angular silhouettes. Floor length day time dresses in cable-stayed plaid and grid lace stove pipe sleeves effortlessly balance geometry with a natural fluidity. Brick fil coupe?, galvanized organza, and silk cloque? are highlighted in colors such as rust, sulfurous amber, dark bronze and white silver.

item.title: KILL ART // TRUST DESIGN 2.0
item.description: KILL ART // TRUST DESIGN 2.0 "Few artists call themselves designers because they seem to better understand the difference. Artists do not create their work to sell a product or promote a service. They create it solely as a means of self-expression, so that it can be viewed and appreciated by others. The message, if we can even call it that, is not a fact but a feeling." Art is Patron-ed, Design is Purchased. Art existed before capitalism, before design was "bought", things were merely improvements or innovations made by intelligent people or practical users. Art is an invention made by an individual, for individual interpretation.
item.content:encoded: KILL ART // TRUST DESIGN 2.0 "Few artists call themselves designers because they seem to better understand the difference. Artists do not create their work to sell a product or promote a service. They create it solely as a means of self-expression, so that it can be viewed and appreciated by others. The message, if we can even call it that, is not a fact but a feeling." Art is Patron-ed, Design is Purchased. Art existed before capitalism, before design was "bought", things were merely improvements or innovations made by intelligent people or practical users. Art is an invention made by an individual, for individual interpretation.

item.title: Generation Praktikum
item.description: Invited to showcase our work in the Design Fair in Frankfurt, we began with the exhibition theme "Private Identity" and adapted it into our response: a pop-up t-shirt store as a commentary on the t-shirt's status as the ultimate embodiment of self-branding. We created a series of 500 unique t-shirts, offering 500 individual identities to the shopper. As each shirt was purchased, we photographed the buyer with their new acquisition. The photograph then was placed where the shirt once hung. As the show progressed, the pop-up shop transformed into a pop-up exhibition: a gallery of portraits revealing views of self-perception and identity. GenerationPraktikum.com
item.content:encoded: Invited to showcase our work in the Design Fair in Frankfurt, we began with the exhibition theme "Private Identity" and adapted it into our response: a pop-up t-shirt store as a commentary on the t-shirt's status as the ultimate embodiment of self-branding. We created a series of 500 unique t-shirts, offering 500 individual identities to the shopper. As each shirt was purchased, we photographed the buyer with their new acquisition. The photograph then was placed where the shirt once hung. As the show progressed, the pop-up shop transformed into a pop-up exhibition: a gallery of portraits revealing views of self-perception and identity. GenerationPraktikum.com

item.title: Steidl - Then & Now Special Edition
item.description: In August of 2005 Steidl published Edward Ruscha's first major photographic multiple object. The project was initiated by Ruscha in 1973 when he photographed all the buildings of the entire length of Hollywood Boulevard in Los Angeles. Echoing his famous artist's book, "Every Building on The Sunset Strip" (1966), he produced two continuous panoramic views of the north and south sides of the street. In 2004 he returned and directed the re-shooting of Hollywood Boulevard to produce two further panoramic images. The 1973 images were made in black and white, and the 2004 in color. These four images were then combined over 142 pages of the artist's book published by Steidl, aligning the 1973 and 2004 images of the north side along the top of the page, and the south side of the boulevard inverted along the bottom of the page. This was Ruscha's first independently produced artist's book since 1978. Gagosian Gallery, in conjunction with Steidl Verlag, was pleased to announce "Ed Ruscha: THEN & NOW," a set of photographic prints that document Hollywood Boulevard, first in 1973 and then thirty-one years later in 2004. This exhibition also marked the ten-year anniversary of Gagosian Gallery Beverly Hills. This Ed Ruscha multiple is a set of 142 photographic prints, housed in a handmade wooden crate signed and numbered in an edition of 10 (with 6 A.P.s). I worked together with printer Gerhard Steidl on the art/photography direction of the project, under the creative direction of artist Ed Ruscha and Gagosian Gallery, Beverly Hills. This project was designed, produced and printed in-house at Steidl Verlag in Gottingën, Germany.
item.content:encoded: In August of 2005 Steidl published Edward Ruscha's first major photographic multiple object. The project was initiated by Ruscha in 1973 when he photographed all the buildings of the entire length of Hollywood Boulevard in Los Angeles. Echoing his famous artist's book, "Every Building on The Sunset Strip" (1966), he produced two continuous panoramic views of the north and south sides of the street. In 2004 he returned and directed the re-shooting of Hollywood Boulevard to produce two further panoramic images. The 1973 images were made in black and white, and the 2004 in color. These four images were then combined over 142 pages of the artist's book published by Steidl, aligning the 1973 and 2004 images of the north side along the top of the page, and the south side of the boulevard inverted along the bottom of the page. This was Ruscha's first independently produced artist's book since 1978. Gagosian Gallery, in conjunction with Steidl Verlag, was pleased to announce "Ed Ruscha: THEN & NOW," a set of photographic prints that document Hollywood Boulevard, first in 1973 and then thirty-one years later in 2004. This exhibition also marked the ten-year anniversary of Gagosian Gallery Beverly Hills. This Ed Ruscha multiple is a set of 142 photographic prints, housed in a handmade wooden crate signed and numbered in an edition of 10 (with 6 A.P.s). I worked together with printer Gerhard Steidl on the art/photography direction of the project, under the creative direction of artist Ed Ruscha and Gagosian Gallery, Beverly Hills. This project was designed, produced and printed in-house at Steidl Verlag in Gottingën, Germany.

item.title: Canadian Centre for Architecture
item.description: Since 2008, Project Projects has collaborated with the Canadian Centre for Architecture in Montreal on exhibition design and graphics for a number of significant shows, including Actions: What You Can Do With the City (November 2008), Speed Limits (May 2009), and Architecture in Uniform: Design and Building for the Second World War (April 2011). Actions explores how everyday human efforts can animate and influence the perception and experience of contemporary cities. Speed Limits examines the pivotal role played by speed in art, architecture, urbanism, graphics, economics, and modern life. Focused particularly on material cultures of the industrial and information eras, the exhibition marked the centenary of the Italian Futurist movement. Curated by Jean-Louis Cohen, Architecture In Uniform fills a significant gap in the history of architecture by investigating the far-reaching contributions made by architects and designers on each side of World War II.
item.content:encoded: Since 2008, Project Projects has collaborated with the Canadian Centre for Architecture in Montreal on exhibition design and graphics for a number of significant shows, including Actions: What You Can Do With the City (November 2008), Speed Limits (May 2009), and Architecture in Uniform: Design and Building for the Second World War (April 2011). Actions explores how everyday human efforts can animate and influence the perception and experience of contemporary cities. Speed Limits examines the pivotal role played by speed in art, architecture, urbanism, graphics, economics, and modern life. Focused particularly on material cultures of the industrial and information eras, the exhibition marked the centenary of the Italian Futurist movement. Curated by Jean-Louis Cohen, Architecture In Uniform fills a significant gap in the history of architecture by investigating the far-reaching contributions made by architects and designers on each side of World War II.

item.title: Grounded Short Film
item.description: One astronaut's journey through space and life ends on a hostile exosolar planet. Grounded is a metaphorical account of the experience, inviting unique interpretation and reflection by the viewer. Themes of aging, inheritance, paternal approval, cyclic trajectories, and behaviors passed on through generations are explored against an ethereal backdrop.
item.content:encoded: One astronaut's journey through space and life ends on a hostile exosolar planet. Grounded is a metaphorical account of the experience, inviting unique interpretation and reflection by the viewer. Themes of aging, inheritance, paternal approval, cyclic trajectories, and behaviors passed on through generations are explored against an ethereal backdrop.
